render.tex: \title{Conditional Probability Notation} Understanding what $P\left( A\,\vert\, B\right),$$P\left( B\,\vert\, A\right)$ and $P\left( A\cap B \right)$ mean

reason.tex:
%text The notation used to express conditional probability has a very special -- and a very precise -- meaning The table below should help you remember \underline\text{when to use which notation} % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{Ncc}
\hline \text{Notation} & \text{What you know} & \text{Probability to find} \\ \hline P\left( A\,\vert\, B\right) & \text{B has happened} & \text{$A$ happened?} \\ \hline P\left( B\,\vert\, A\right) & \text{A has happened} & \text{$B$ happened?} \\ \hline P\left(A\cap B\right) & \text{Nothing} & \text{$A$ and $B$} \\ & & \text{happening together} \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text %
